title: 30 years of Nissan: How the Sunderland plant transformed the North East
text:
30 years of Nissan: How the Sunderland plant transformed the North East 00:01, 8 Sep 2016 By Robert Gibson MD Kevin Fitzpatrick on how the factory enhanced the UK supply chain and opened doors for other automotive giants Shares Get business news by email Kevin Fitzpatrick vice president UK manufacturing operations Nissan Sunderland 
As Nissan’s Sunderland plant marks 30 years since its official opening, Robert Gibson finds out how the factory has transformed the North East and UK manufacturing as a whole. 
On September 8, 1986, then Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher opened the Nissan plant in Sunderland with the hope that it would “provide a steadily growing number of jobs in an area which really needs them” and “show in the clearest possible way how such areas can help to recover their prosperity and self esteem”. 
At the time the plant, Nissan Motor Manufacturing UK employed slightly less than 500 people and in its first year built 5,000 cars. 
30 years on from that day, there are 7,000 people people directly employed at Nissan and a further 40,000 in its supply chain. The factory now produces more than 500,000 vehicles a year and exports to more than 130 different countries. 
“The impact has been massive - not just locally but nationally,” said MD Kevin Fitzpatrick, one of 115 members of staff who have been at the plant for its entire history (starting as supervisor of its paint shop). PA Wire An aerial view of cars at Nissan 
“There wasn’t a supply base in the North East when we started, but through the local contract requirement with the Government, we started getting parts in Europe and the UK and set the local supply base up. 
“At first that was pretty poor in terms of meeting delivery and quality standards, but Nissan worked by itself and through a Government agency to train the supply base in modern manufacturing.” 
Without the company’s lead, Mr Fitzpatrick said, it was unlikely UK manufacturing would be as competitive as it now. 
“We opened the door for the likes of Toyota and Honda to come here,” he said. “I don’t know if they would have done otherwise.” 
In the factory’s early days, he said, there was a “cynical view” in some quarters that the company would likely disappear from the North East within five years. 
At the same time, it was “very exciting” for the new recruits, many of whom were eager to leave traditional industries behind them and embrace the “great opportunities to learn” that Nissan represented. 
One of the of biggest changes to take place over the years, he added, has been the increased use of robotics, with the plant now 95% automated. 
As far as output is concerned, a Qashqai can built in 8.5 hours, compared to 22 hours for the Bluebird, the first car to come from the site, 
NMUK Sunderland has also become a leader in pioneering green technology, producing the Nissan Leaf, and committing to a £26.5m investment to produce the future generation of electric vehicle batteries. 
The site is likewise embracing the latest developments in autonomous driving technology, which will next year make its way into the Qashqai. 
As Mr Fitzpatrick pointed out, however, it hasn’t always been plain sailing; in the late ‘90s, for example, poor sales of models such as the Primera caused significant upheaval, leading to the signing of the Renault-Nissan Alliance. 
“We knew we were good, but we had to demonstrate to Renault that we were good,” he said. 
“We spent a lot of time doing that and on improving ourselves, which led to a step-change in our competitiveness.” 
A decade on, then, there was the economic crash to contend with. 
“We were still doing what we normally do, then pretty much overnight, people stopped buying cars,” Mr Fitzpatrick said. 
“It was pretty scary and we didn’t know how to combat it. There had been uncertainty before, but we had never had that kind of crisis.” 
In the end, around 800 employees were lost their jobs. Aerial view of Nissan in 1986 
Nissan, however, bounced back swiftly and many were re-hired, benefiting from the “turning point” that was the success of the Qashqai and the Juke. 
Today, the company continues to place significant emphasis on its skilled workforce, offering career development programmes, graduate schemes, initiatives with schools and, of course, apprenticeships. 
“I’ve always thought apprenticeships were a good way of developing people within manufacturing and engineering,” Mr Fitzpatrick said. 
“When I was 16, I couldn’t face another two years in the classroom; I wanted to learn and gain qualifications, but I also wanted to get out and make money. It’s the same for lots of people, but I think many are denied that opportunity.” 
As it looks to the future, Nissan will be paying close attention to discussions surrounding Brexit. 
Mr Fitzpatrick would not be drawn on the implications of the EU referendum vote on the Sunderland site, though comments from Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe earlier this week highlighted concerns among Japanese companies about Brexit. 
The company’s global CEO Carlos Ghosn had called for a Remain vote before June’s referendum, and has made it clear since then that the company hopes the UK will retain its ability to export easily into the European Union. 30 years of Nissan 
Nissan announces that the plant will be located in Sunderland. 
Ground breaking ceremony takes place. 
A ceremony is held to lay the foundation stone. Diggers move in to start construction, with constructors McAlpine managing the project. 1985 
The first group of 22 supervisors joins the company. 
The completed factory, which took a record 62 weeks to build, is handed over to Nissan. 1986 
The first Nissan Bluebird rolls off the production line. 
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher officially opens the plant. 1987 
Phase II building work gets underway. 1988 
Employment at the plant reaches 1,300. 
Exports begin of left-hand drive cars to nine European markets. 1990 
Construction of phase II is completed. 
Bluebird production ends and production of the Nissan Primera begins. 1991 
100,000 Primeras completed. 1992 
Nissan announces a further £200m investment, raising total investment to £900m, the largest single Japanese inward investment in Europe. 
Production of the Nissan Micra begins. 1994 
Sunderland Plant is named Britain’s biggest car exporter in 1993, when 182,194 Primeras and Micras were exported to 36 world markets. 1995 
Production milestone of one millionth vehicle is achieved. 1996 
Production of the new Primera begins. 1997 
NMUK announces the introduction of a third model, the new Almera, in 2000, bringing an additional investment of £215m. 1998 
Production of the Primera Estate begins - NMUK produces over 20,000 during 1998. 1999 
800 new staff recruited from over 11,000 applicants. 
The Renault-Nissan Alliance is signed, the first of its kind involving a Japanese and a French company. The Alliance is ranked amongst the world’s top five leading automakers. 
One millionth Micra is produced and Nissan becomes the first Japanese manufacturer in Europe to reach this landmark. One millionth Primera produced. 2000 
Sunderland becomes a three-model plant with production starting of the new Almera. Full production is ramped up in a European record of six weeks. 
The plant produces 300,000 cars a year for the first time. 2001 
The next generation Primera begins production, it is the first representation of Nissan’s new product direction with bold styling, innovative design and advanced, yet easy to use technology. Full production was ramped up in only 5.4 weeks. 2002 
The new Micra begins production, ramping up to full production in five weeks. 2004 
SMMT names Sunderland as the biggest plant for the sixth consecutive year (1998-2003) and Nissan as the biggest UK car producer for four years (2000-2003). 
The millionth car is produced for the UK market, a Nissan Micra. 2005 
The Micra C+C enters production. 
The first six wind turbines are switched on. A further four are added and together in total they generate 8% of the plant’s electricity. 2006 
The Note goes into production and the new model is ramped up to full production in a record three weeks. 
The 4 millionth engine is produced, the last Nissan Almera is produced and the Qashqai goes into production. 2007 
Sunderland plant hits the 4.5m production mark. 
Primera production ends. 2008 
Sunderland plant announces 800 new jobs and the introduction of a third production shift to help meet Qashqai demand. This will also include a further 400 jobs in the supply chain. 
Axle shop is expanded with a further 128 jobs and £5m investment. 
During a visit to the UK, Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn announces a 12th new model for Sunderland Plant, a compact car which will be launched in 2010 and based on the concept model Qazana, which was unveiled at the Geneva Motorshow in 2009. 
Start of production of QASHQAI +2. 2009 
Prime Minister Gordon Brown and Business Secretary Lord Mandelson visit the plant for the announcement of Nissan’s intention to build an advanced lithium-ion battery manufacturing plant in the UK and one in Portugal. 2010 
Production of the convertible Micra C+C ends. 
Nissan announces Sunderland Plant as the European manufacturing location for the Nissan Leaf. 
After 18 years, more than 2.3m units and one model change, Micra production ends at the plant. 
Juke goes into production. 2011 
Sunderland plant is recognised by the SMMT as the UK’s largest car producer and the biggest car exporter for the 13th year running and exporter for the 11th year. Sunderland Plant produces its six millionth car, a Juke. Nissan is the first car manufacturer in the UK to make more than 400,000 units in one year. 
Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn announces that the next generation Qashqai will be built in Britain. 
Sunderland produces its one millionth Qashqai, four years, six months and 23 days after production began on December 5th, 2006. No other UK-built car has reached the million mark in such a short space of time. 2012 
Juke Nismo goes into production. The car is the first in the range of Nissan cars to take Nissan’s wealth of global motorsport success from the race track to the road. 
Record production year for the plant and the UK car industry with 510,572 units produced. 
The announcement is made during a visit from former UK Business Secretary Vince Cable that a new model under the company’s premium brand, Infiniti, would be manufactured at NMUK. This £250m investment will create 280 jobs at the plant and marks the first time an Infiniti model is manufactured in Europe. 2013 
NMUK produces its seven millionth car. 
The 100% electric Nissan Leaf goes into production. The event is attended by former UK Prime Minister David Cameron. 
New Note goes into production at the plant. An event is held with former UK Business Minister Michael Fallon. 
A ground breaking ceremony takes place at NMUK to officially launch the start of construction of the 25,000m2 extensions to the plant’s Body Shop and Trim and Chassis line 2 for Infiniti production. The event is attended by Nissan Chief Performance Officer Trevor Mann. 2014 
New Qashqai production begins. The vehicle is named What Car? 2014 Car of the Year. 
Nissan launches the Nissan Skills Foundation – a major expansion of its schools engagement activities in the UK, using electric vehicles, motorsports and its manufacturing excellence to excite thousands of young people about careers in industry. 
The Qashqai makes UK automotive history by becoming the fastest model to reach the two million mark. 2015 
HRH Prince Charles visits the plant. During his visit, His Royal Highness sees production on line 1 and meets some of the students involved in the Nissan Skills Foundation. 
The new Qashqai reaches the half million production milestone. 
A major £37m expansion to the plant’s Press Shop is announced with the introduction of a new XL press. 
Infiniti Q30 goes into production. 2016 
Nissan announces its commitment to produce the future generation electric vehicle (EV) batteries at NMUK. This represents a further £26.5m investment. 
The announcement is made that Qashqai will also be built on line 2. 
A further £22m investment announcement is made for additional Qashqai capacity from 2017. 
The plant starts generating power for a 4.75MW capacity solar farm, based on the plant’s test track. The 19,000 photo-voltaic panels along with the plant’s 10 wind turbines will provide 7% of the plants electricity. 
QX30 goes into production and is exported to the US 0 the first time the plant has made a car for the US market.
